s.text: A Pontiac Bonneville is as rare a sight in Seoul as an Aston-Martin is here.

Such seems to be the curious strategy of the world auto industry in the late 1990s, as it grapples with prices that are actually declining, demand that's stagnant, and production capacity that, against all good sense, just keeps getting bigger.
Hyundai--formerly the Yugo's poor cousin--is increasing capital spending by 700 percent.
Overcapacity is, in any case, difficult to measure, since it's more important for car companies to be able to meet increases in demand than it is for them to make only as many cars as customers want.

Except, of course, that if you do you lose all hope of capturing what market does exist, and except, of course, that when you stop making cars, you have to close factories and throw people out of work.

Such seems to be the curious strategy of the world auto industry in the late 1990s, as it grapples with prices that are actually declining, demand that's stagnant, and production capacity that, against all good sense, just keeps getting bigger.

Such seems to be the curious strategy of the world auto industry in the late 1990s, as it grapples with prices that are actually declining, demand that's stagnant, and production capacity that, against all good sense, just keeps getting bigger.
What's curious is that no one is really doing anything about it.
